threads.com:
Hello anons, i was using CRTs from a month or so, and i really like the tech, and i desire to get more performance out of then, however, this tech is dead from 15 years or so

And i want to change that, so, please, provide any sort of datasheet, about all the formulas that are needed, and components required
as far as i know, i would need a 2.36GHz and a 365KHz clock to have 480 Hz of Vertical refresh rate

Any help provided would be helpfull, since i plan on making these fuckers into the today

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89941517
>And i want to change that, so, please, provide any sort of datasheet, about all the formulas that are needed, and components required
>as far as i know, i would need a 2.36GHz and a 365KHz clock to have 480 Hz of Vertical refresh rate

That's not how this works, kid.

These appliances were designed by large, well organized teams of highly educated engineers and reiterated over decades of trail and error with an manufacturing infrastructure that doesn't exist anymore. You will NOT be able to devise and design your own overclocker's crt upgrade pcb or some shit like that just all by yourself.

Start with something current like getting into FPGAs and try getting into actual, live projects that try to do the same for lcds. Don't waste time on old tech and trying to outsmart long dead boomer engineers 2 standard deviations above your I.Q. when you can actually try and learn from actual living people how to do current shit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89941677
hint: there's physical limits to crt tubes themselves and you will you have to account for stuff like heating and reluctance in the coil windings and much more stuff like that. You basically will end up stripping down even the crt tube to it's base minimum and will have to make your own coil windings for your idea to go anywhere, this is not worth the effort and will go nowhere.
These boomers really peaked the tech in the mid 20s with stuff like that revered 16:10 sony monitor. Again, you wont outsmart those guys and I know kids like you, I was one myself - you are just wasting precious time pondering retarded ideas while instead you could be learning worthwhile, current tech related topics.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89941576
720p scales extremely horribly on 4K displays (ie not a lot of 1440p LED TVs AFAIK). It should be the absolute last resort. Hell transcoding 540p video out of 1080p video would probably be better scaling on a 4K display than 720p video.

540p/2160p = 0.25 or 4X
720p/2160p = 0.33 or 3X

threads.com:
Hello /g/,

I had an idea for a VR controller method that I don’t see being done anywhere.

It would be a glove that maximizes both function and compatibility, while also being affordable. It would work like so:

1. It would consist of a pair of gloves tracked positionally in VR, emulating a Valve Knuckles controller.

2. The gloves would track your fingers and output their positions to software to mimic the output of the Knuckles’ capacitive sensors.

3. Each glove would be paired wirelessly with an untracked controller, that would attach itself magnetically to either the wrist or the palm of the hand.
3a. When attached to the palms, they would have face buttons and a joystick with identical outputs as Knuckles.
3b. When unattached or attached to the wrist, become inactive.


This is the best controller idea in a generation that would be very inexpensive while allowing outright superior VR experiences.

You could also sell more expensive versions along side it that include support for haptics and force feedback to future proof the brand and concept.

>>89936905
it can happen in languages where the default call stack size is especially limited, e.g. java (you'll start hitting overflows around 1024 calls deep by default).
if you wrap your code in a couple of frameworks and make liberal use of streams (each call adds like 5+ stack frames) you might end up touching the limit in a complex application.
but the solution is pretty simple: just crank up the call stack size, it doesn't cost *that* much.

No such thing, most shitdroid phones have:
A.) low quality lithium batteries with only 0.5C peak discharge rates (ie why they take 2 hours to charge to 100%)
B.) 0 passive cooling on the SoC which causes throttling to occur within seconds
C.) usually configured for ~10H OST discharge profiles at the factory (ie ~1 watt average power consumption) so they heavily throttle even if A and B weren't applicable.

It doesn't help that iPhone SoCs only require 50% of the power to do the same work of a qualcom SoC which is why 6,000 mAh is becoming the new norm on android phones.

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.
(Does not work on VL editions that need KMS, avoid VL/KMS)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i

There are no compatibility differences between versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html

last_replies.com:
>>89935497
Hearing the difference now isn't the reason to encode to FLAC. FLAC uses lossless compression, while MP3 is 'lossy'. What this means is that for each year the MP3 sits on your hard drive, it will lose roughly 12kbps, assuming you have SATA - it's about 15kbps on IDE, but only 7kbps on SCSI, due to rotational velocidensity. You don't want to know how much worse it is on CD-ROM or other optical media.

I started collecting MP3s in about 2001, and if I try to play any of the tracks I downloaded back then, even the stuff I grabbed at 320kbps, they just sound like crap. The bass is terrible, the midrange…well don’t get me started. Some of those albums have degraded down to 32 or even 16kbps. FLAC rips from the same period still sound great, even if they weren’t stored correctly, in a cool, dry place. Seriously, stick to FLAC, you may not be able to hear the difference now, but in a year or two, you’ll be glad you did.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89927864
All computers that used motorola based processors eventually died off in favor of Intel's x86, PowerPC and (to a lesser extent) MIPS. The only reason the Amiga was able to hold on for as long as it did is stuff like the video toaster, animation, cheap 3D, and had all of those music trackers. It was the best price for performance for like half a decade. It did for artists in the late 80s and early 90s what Macs did for desktop publishing in the mid 80s (though, Apple would have the capital and smart enough management to move on from Motorolas, even if the move was a clusterfuck). Amigas sort of hung on because the artists it attracted, visual or audio artists, reallly liked the workflow they had developed in the Amiga environment. Some boomers even used MorphOS on PowerPC Macs for decades as a cope.

This is the last thing I wrote, which I use when I write Python at work.
(defun my/dap-dwim-eval-repl ()
    "Evaluate code in the dap-debug repl.
If a region is active, evaluate the active region.
Otherwise evaluate the current line."
    (interactive)
    (if (use-region-p)
        (insert-into-buffer
         (get-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*") (mark) (point))
      (insert-into-buffer (get-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*")
                          (line-beginning-position)
                          (line-end-position)))
    (with-current-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*"
      (comint-send-input)))


This takes the marked region, or current line if no region is active, and evaluates
it in the interactive debugging window. Basically, this lets me start the debugger and
write and evaluate code on the fly. It's like a poor man's lisp repl, at least as far as development is concerned. I probably use it 20+ times a day.
I assume that Vim could accomplish this with macros and vscode with a plugin, so I'm not claiming that only emacs can do this. I am just claiming that it is easier in Emacs.

(defun u/duration-from-seconds (s)
  "Interpret s as a duration in seconds and return a list representing that duration as (days hours minutes seconds)."
  (let* ((days    (/ s  (* 24 60 60)))
         (dr      (% s  (* 24 60 60)))
         (hours   (/ dr (* 60 60)))
         (hr      (% dr (* 60 60)))
         (minutes (/ hr 60))
         (seconds (% hr 60)))
    (list days hours minutes seconds)))

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Encryption guide for retards which is going to trigger other retards. Do what you will with this information:

>Safest option
TCG Opal SED + dmcrypt/LUKS
>Safe option
dmcrypt/LUKS

Everything below should not be considered safe:

>Safest non-safe option
TCG Opal SED + Bitlocker
>Second safest non-safe option
TCG Opal SED only
>Third safest non-safe option
Bitlocker/Veracrypt

>inb4 "WHY BITLOCKER INSTEAD OF VERACRYPT OMG GLOWNIGGER"
I don't recommend Bitlocker nor Veracrypt as you can see above. I consider both unsafe options because 1. Both Bitlocker and Veracrypt will run on top of Windows which means both will be compromised anyway. The Windows OS has full access to your memory and at least Bitlocker can make use of TPM. In addition, unlike Bitlocker Veracrypt will absolutely rape your SSD's performance.
>inb4 "TCG OPAL WAS COMPROMISED AND IT'S NOT SAFER THAN BITLOCKER"
Well, not really. The first iterations of SEDs from shitty manufacturers like Crucial were indeed kinda compromised. What these idiots did was providing a default master password for their SEDs which could be fixed by either setting a master password or setting ATA_SECURITY_LEVEL to MAX. The advantage over Bitlocker or Truecrypt is that SED encryption/decryption is in no way related to your OS. Your OS doesn't know anything about it which is why I consider it safer than Bitlocker or Veracrypt on Windows(!).

I don't consider TCG Opal safe but I would still use it on top of dmcrypt/LUKS because why not? There is no performance penalty and you're adding another layer of security. If it gets broken, so what? There's still dmcrypt. No reason not to make a potential attacker's life easier.

>tl;dr
If you're worried about law enforcement your only safe option is SED + dmycrypt/luks or dymcrypt/luks. If you're only worried about niggers you can simply set a password to your SED. No need to run software encryption on top of it and lower performance. No nigger is going to break your SED.

Voltage leak from NAND occurs slower at lower temps. Refrigeration temperatures is literally all you need for cheap 3D NAND consumer SSDs to hold their data for 5-10 years. 2-bit MLC enterprise SSDs will go beyond 10 years, possibly even 15 years (we literally need a time machine for this).

Why have people become so sensitive when it comes to PSUs?

Remember when everybody just bought grey $30 Ching chong units without a second thought?
Yeah some indeed went bang and probably created the myth, but why should I be scared of my twice as expensive certified unit from Europe, North America or non shithole Asia doing the same?

Are you telling me that a 500W bronze PSU can't handle an 3070 or 6800? Why does it have 2 8 pin connectors and the capability to deliver 456W through them according to the manufacturer then?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89938161
No, they're wrong entirely. Most full size PCs idle in the 60-100 watt range,
Most gold rated PSUs are 83-85% or efficient at their 10% load.

My Seasonic focus plus 850 platinum for example is ~86-88% efficient in the 70-85 watt range of my typical PC idle.
But yes, all PSUs efficiency drops rapidly below that 10%, even the titanium ones (just not as badly).
It's just not nearly as bad as that poster suggested. He's an idiot.

go to cybenetics.com and look for your power supply, or the most similar model, and look at their testing PDFs.
here's mine, in US of Clapistan at 115V house power, I can see an 85 watt load on my 850w PSU is ~87.5% efficient.
A titanium class PSU is only guaranteed for ~90% at the same level. Not worth the extra $$

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89938161
And just to do some quick math, the power cost difference between 85 and 88% efficient at 85 watts is ~10USD/10euro per year, for a full 365 day of 24 hour idle, and thats at a 35cent per kilowatt hour rate (i pay ~17.5 cent/kwh after adding taxes and fees - the avg reported power cost for most of US is bullshit)
For typical people the extreme price difference between a gold and titanium is not worth it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89931548
It's mostly pointless to test ATX PSUs because there's literally no guarantee of what their guts are
There's a handful of big companies building ATX power supplies plus a bunch of obscure chink factories that change their name every time their reputation goes in the toilet. Very few companies actually brand the power supplies they make with their own name
There's been some cases where a brand name PSU had guts available from two entirely different OEMs based on entirely different designs with no way to find out besides popping the cover on it
There have also been cases where the quality of the PSU guts has lowered significantly from the review samples sent out because chink factories are run by assholes
This is why you should only ever buy power supplies from companies that actually manufacture their own since it's their reputation on the line when they make shit. Seasonic and FSP are the two main players still branding as themselves.

Alternatively, if your system is like mine then the "usual" interface you're connecting to the computer on is actually terminal 7 or something like that, and you can use a certain key combination to switch to terminal 1 or 2 (maybe both), which are generally non-GUI terminals you can log into (even if you're logged in with the same account on your graphical terminal) that you can use to kill the frozen process and then switch back to terminal 7 to see if that recovered it.
